SafetyInspectionBy: New York State Department of Labor

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
I.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES

     Freezer Queen recognizes management's responsibility in protecting it's employees, equipment, property, and the environment. The safety and health of all personnel are very important.  The control of ammonia release incidents has been and will continue to be the basic responsibility of all Freezer Queen personnel who operate the Ammonia Refrigeration System.

     The Freezer Queen PSM/RMP program assigns and documents the specific responsibilities for developing, implementing and integrating the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP standards into its Ammonia Operating and Management Systems.  The Freezer Queen PSM/RMP program focuses attention on "Making PSM/RMP the way we manage our ammonia based refrigeration system" rather than a project we expect to complete and put on the shelf when the filing date has passed.

     Freezer Queen believes that Employee Participation is the key to a successful PSM/RMP program.  Operating level employees, particularly the Engine Room Manager and the Principle Chief Refrigeration Engineer, have been deeply involved and they (along with the Refrigeration System Operators) assume the major responsibility for operating the Hazardous Material process safely.

     The Freezer Queen Emergency Response Program has been developed in cooperation, and with the support of the local Public Emergency Response Agency.  All Freezer Queen employees have received documented emergency response training.


II.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

     Freezer Queen operates an Ammonia Refrigeration System.  Ammonia is a common industrial chemical with applications in a large number of industries such as Agriculture, Water Treatment, Food Storage Warehouses, Pharmaceuticals, Heat Treating and many, many more.  Ammonia has been listed by both EPA and OSHA as Hazardous Substance.


III.  SUMMARY OF WORST CASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS

Dispersion cloud modeling studies have be

en performed as required by PSM/RMP regulations and the information developed has been used in the preparation of the Technical Studies and Reports that are also required.  The information has been distributed to local emergency response agencies when requested on a "Need to Know" basis.


IV.   DESCRIPTION OF THE Freezer Queen ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

     Freezer Queen conducts annual in house emergency action training and maintains a relationship the local Public Emergency Response Agency to practice and update their Emergency Response Program

     Freezer Queen conducts an annual PSM/RMP progress audit of their PSM/RMP program to identify strengths and weaknesses and make improvements. Freezer Queen considers the PSM/RMP manuals to be a "living" documents that must be updated and revised regularly to maintain their viability and usefulness.

     Freezer Queen emphasizes and insists on "employee participation" from their ammonia process operators in all aspects of the development, implementation, and integration of their PSM/RMP program.

    Freezer Queen provides a comprehensive, computer based, user friendly training program and management system with "one-on-one" teacher involvement in specific training modules for each ammonia process employee.

     Freezer Queen maintains a pro-active "open-door" policy toward neighbors and concerned community citizens.  Facility tours and risk management discussions are scheduled and conducted upon written request.

V.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENTAL RELEASE HISTORY

     There have been no releases of ammonia during the past five years that resulted in an injury, or that had an off-site impact, or that resulted in significant property damage either on-site or off-site.

VI.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

     Facility employees have been trained to respond to accidental ammonia releases on a "defensive" Emergency Action basis.  They do no mainain an incident commander with personnel trained and equipped to enter a ID

LH ammonia atmosphere.  The site emergency plan has been coordinated with local Public Emergency  Responders.

VII.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

   
     Freezer Queen  recognizes that even good PSM/RMP Programs require constant attention and improvement.  The PSM/RMP program is considered to be a set of "living" documents and procedures that will require constant attention, development, and revision before "Safety" truly becomes "second nature".

      Freezer Queen expects to improve PSM/RMP and safety performance by emphasizing the following elements of their PSM/RMP Program:

 (1)   EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  Employee Participation is the "Key" to a successful program. Ammonia Process Managers and Operators have been deeply involved in Verifying P&ID's, Developing and updating the Standard Operating Procedures, and performing the documented Preventive Maintenance Inspections.

(2)    EXPANCED USE OF THEIR PSM/RMP WEB-SITE:   The Freezer Queen PSM/RMP Program is:  (a) computer based,  (b) user friendly,  (c) includes "one-on-one" involvement with specified and qualified trainers,  (d) written to minimize paperwork and maximize documentation, and  (e) written to be understood and used by both Ammonia Managers and Process Operators.  The web-site makes all information developed by the PSM/RMP Program available to all employees who have a User Name and Password.  All Refrigeration System employees have an assigned User Name and Password. 

(3)  PROCESS HAZARDS ANALYSIS: All recommendations developed during the Process Hazards Analysis (PHA) were designed to improve the safety performance of the Ammonia Refrigeration System].   Freezer Queen has evaluated each PHA recommendation.  Each recommendation has been installed and will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.

(4) AUDITS:   Programs are audited Tri-Annually as required by the OSHA PSM to improve Safety Performance as well as to verify compliance w

ith the PSM/RMP Regulations. 

(5)  STANDARD OPERATING PROCEDURES:  SOP's are certified annually to be current and correct.  They are revised as often as necessary to keep them current and correct.

(6)  TRAINING:  Orientation Training (both classroom and On-the-Job) is provided employees before Ammonia related work assignments are given.  Renewal training, including documented training tests are provided annually.

(7)  PREVENTIVE MAINTENANCE INSPECTIONS:  Critical Ammonia Equipment is routinely inspected and maintained according to manufacturer?s recommendations.

(8)  PROCESS SAFETY INFORMATION is modified and updated as required by Management of Change modifications.  Freezer Queen has excellent P&ID's that are carefully and regularly updated.
